3: If you enjoy textfiles.com, tweet about it with hashtag #textfiles.
10: T E X T F I L E S
12: On the face of things, we seem to be merely talking about text-based files
On the face of things, we seem to be merely talking about text-based files, containing only the letters
13: of the English Alphabet (and the occasional punctuation mark).
15: On deeper inspection, of course, this isn't quite the case. What this site offers is a glimpse into the
16: history of writers and artists bound by the 128 characters that the American Standard Code for
17: Information Interchange (ASCII) allowed them. The focus is on mid-1980's textfiles and the world as it
18: was then, but even these files are sometime retooled 1960s and 1970s works, and offshoots of this
38: ≪ ↑ ↓ Viewing <T E X T F I L E S D O T C O M>
≪ ↑ ↓ Viewing <T E X T F I L E S D O T C O M>

5: The files on TEXTFILES.COM are maintained by somewhat arbitrary guidelines, so if a file you're looking for is not in one section, try a few others.
6: Files are often in the "8+3" format, but since they're coming from all sorts of sources, this isn't guaranteed. Our focus is on the years 1980-1995,
7: but files from before and after sometime sneak in.

2: Your one-stop shop for all files of a "computery" nature, that cover how to rebuild a piece of computer hardware to do something it was never meant to do, or to see

3: someone go really deeply into a computing subject that would cause most people to yawn and look for the snack table. Since BBSes were on computers, it was natural for
4: people who used BBSes to focus on all aspects of these wonderful machines. The evidence of their interest and their experimentation resides below.
6: Of course, nearly ALL textfiles are computer-related in some fashion, and some subjects might fit here but fit even better in another section. For example, you should
7: sections as well, as you might not agree with what I decided should go where.

8: > Some are obviously still used for their original purpose (CR, LF, the
9: > tabbing codes etc.) but what did ENQ, EM, SUB, FS, etc. do? Thanks,
11: - - - here's a reply I posted a year ago in June - - -
13: Subject: Re: original uses of ASCII control codes
17: To understand the original intent of the ASCII control codes, you have
18: to think of teletypes, using paper tape, configured in a multidrop
19: system with relay logic used to turn on or off individual teletypes in
20: the bunch, and you have to remember that the designers were pretty
21: smart and they anticipated future developments, but they also managed
22: to include provisions for things that never happened.  Here are the
23: ASCII control characters, and a few others, with comments on how they
24: were supposed to be used and how this relates to current popular uses:
28: NULL  00 ^@   always ignored -- leader and trailer on paper tape
29: systems was typically made of sequences of NULLs.
31: SOH   01 ^A   start of heading -- imagine a heading containing, for
32: example, the address of the recipient.  You could have
33: relay logic that scans for SOH, then enables the print
34: mechanism if the following character matches this
35: station's address.  In early documentation, this was
36: called start of message.

38: Do you want to exit w3m? (y/n)
